definitions.definition: To move swiftly.

subdefinitions.definition: ( intransitive ) To move forward quickly upon two feet by alternately making a short jump off either foot.
examples: Run , and you might still catch the train!

subdefinitions.definition: ( intransitive ) To go at a fast pace; to move quickly .
examples: I have been running all over the building looking for him.
Sorry, I've got to run ; my house is on fire!

subdefinitions.definition: ( transitive ) To cover (a course or a distance) by running.
examples: I can run a mile, but I can't run the cross-country course.

subdefinitions.definition: ( transitive ) To complete a running course or event in (a given time).
examples: I was hoping to make the team, but I didn't run the qualifying time.

subdefinitions.definition: ( intransitive ) To move briskly or smoothly with a motion of sliding, rolling, sweeping etc.
examples: The shuttle runs back and forth on these rollers.
As its name suggests, the monorail runs on a single rail.
I felt her fingers running over my cheek.

subdefinitions.definition: ( transitive ) To cause to move quickly or lightly .
examples: Every day I run my dog across the field and back.
I'll just run the vacuum cleaner over the carpet.
Run your fingers through my hair.

subdefinitions.definition: ( transitive or intransitive ) To compete in a race .
examples: The horse will run in the Preakness next year.
I'm not ready to run a marathon.
The car could not be repaired in time for the race and did not run .

subdefinitions.definition: ( transitive ) To transport (someone or something), notionally at a brisk pace.
examples: Could you run me over to the store?
Please run this report upstairs to director's office.

subdefinitions.definition: ( transitive , intransitive ) Of a means of transportation: to travel (a route ).
examples: The bus (train, plane, ferry boat, etc) runs between Newport and Riverside.

subdefinitions.definition: ( transitive ) To cause (a  vehicle) to  travel a route.
( transitive ) To transit (a length of a river), as in whitewater rafting .
( intransitive ) Of fish, to migrate for spawning .
( American football , transitive or intransitive ) To carry (a football ) down the field, as opposed to passing or kicking.
( intransitive ) To flee from a danger or towards help.
examples: Whenever things get tough, she cuts and runs .
When he's broke, he runs to me for money.
When the alarm went off, the thief dropped the booty and ran .

subdefinitions.definition: ( figurative , transitive ) To pass (without stopping ), typically a stop signal , stop sign , or duty to yield the right of way .
examples: The car in front just ran a red light.
If you have a collision with a vehicle oncoming from the right, after having run priority to the right, you are at fault.

subdefinitions.definition: ( transitive , juggling , colloquial ) To juggle a pattern continuously , as opposed to starting and stopping quickly.

definitions.definition: ( fluids ) To flow.

subdefinitions.definition: ( intransitive ) Of a liquid , to flow .
examples: The river runs through the forest into the North Sea.
There's blood running down your leg.

subdefinitions.definition: ( intransitive , figuratively ) To move or spread quickly.
examples: There's a strange story running around the neighborhood that you had a miscarriage last year.
The flu is running through my daughter's kindergarten.

subdefinitions.definition: ( intransitive ) Of an object, to have a liquid flowing from it.
examples: Your nose is running and your forehead is run ning with sweat.
Why is the hose still running ?
I got tears run ning down my cheeks because he smoke of cigars makes my eyes run .

subdefinitions.definition: ( transitive ) To make a liquid flow; to make liquid flow from or into an object.
examples: I can't stop my nose from run ning snot down into my mouth.
Could you run a bath for me, please? You'll have to run the water a while before it gets hot.

subdefinitions.definition: ( intransitive ) To become liquid ; to melt .
( intransitive ) To leak or spread in an undesirable fashion; to bleed (especially used of dye or paint ).
examples: During washing, the red from the rug ran onto the white sheet, staining it pink.

subdefinitions.definition: To fuse ; to shape ; to mould ; to cast .
examples: to run bullets

definitions.definition: ( nautical , of a vessel ) To sail before the wind, in distinction from reaching or sailing close-hauled .
( transitive ) To control or manage ; to be in charge of.
examples: My uncle ran a corner store for forty years.
She runs the fundraising.
My parents think they run my life.
He is running the candidate's expensive campaign.

definitions.definition: ( intransitive ) To be a candidate in an election .
examples: I have decided to run for governor of California.
We're trying to find somebody to run against him next year.

definitions.definition: To make participate in certain kinds of competitions.

subdefinitions.definition: ( transitive ) To make enter a race.
examples: He ran his best horse in the Derby.
We're running two cars in today's rally.

subdefinitions.definition: ( transitive ) To make stand in an election.
examples: The Green Party is running twenty candidates in this election.

definitions.definition: To exert continuous activity; to proceed.
examples: to run through life; to run in a circle

definitions.definition: ( intransitive ) To be presented in the media .
examples: The story will run on the 6-o'clock news.
The latest Robin Williams movie is running at the Silver City theatre.
Her picture ran on the front page of the newspaper.

definitions.definition: ( transitive ) To print or broadcast in the media.
examples: run a story; run an ad

definitions.definition: ( transitive ) To smuggle ( illegal goods).
examples: They are run ning guns to the rebels.

definitions.definition: ( transitive , agriculture ) To sort through a large volume of produce in quality control .
examples: Looks like we're gonna have to run the tomatoes again.

definitions.definition: To extend or persist, statically or dynamically, through space or time.

subdefinitions.definition: ( intransitive ) To extend in space or through a range (often with a measure phrase).
examples: The border runs for 3000 miles.
The leash runs along a wire.
The grain of the wood runs to the right on this table.
It ran in quality from excellent to substandard.

subdefinitions.definition: ( intransitive ) To extend in time , to last , to continue (usually with a measure phrase).
examples: The sale will run for ten days.
The contract runs through 2008.
The meeting ran late.
The book runs 655 pages.
The speech runs as follows: …

subdefinitions.definition: ( transitive ) To make (something) extend in space.
examples: I need to run this wire along the wall.

subdefinitions.definition: ( intransitive ) Of a machine , including computer programs , to be operating or working normally.
examples: My car stopped running .
That computer runs twenty-four hours a day.
The buses don't run on Sundays.

subdefinitions.definition: ( transitive ) To make a machine operate .
examples: It's full. You can run the dishwasher now.
Don't run the engine so fast.

definitions.definition: ( transitive ) To execute or carry out a plan , procedure , or program .
examples: They ran twenty blood tests on me and they still don't know what's wrong.
Our coach had us running plays for the whole practice.
I will run the sample.
Don't run that software unless you have permission.
My computer is too old to run the new OS.

definitions.definition: To pass or go quickly in thought or conversation.
examples: to run from one subject to another

definitions.definition: ( copulative ) To become different in a way mentioned (usually to become worse ).
examples: Our food supplies are running low because money is run ning short .
They frequently overspent and soon ran into debt.
Tap water always run s freezing cold before run ning dry .

definitions.definition: ( transitive ) To cost an amount of money.
examples: Buying a new laptop will run you a thousand dollars.
Laptops run about a thousand dollars apiece.

definitions.definition: ( intransitive ) Of stitches or stitched clothing, to unravel .
examples: My stocking is running .

definitions.definition: ( transitive ) To cause stitched clothing to unravel.
To pursue in thought; to carry in contemplation.
To cause to enter; to thrust.
examples: to run a sword into or through the body; to run a nail into one's foot

definitions.definition: To drive or force; to cause, or permit, to be driven.
To cause to be drawn; to mark out; to indicate; to determine.
examples: to run a line

definitions.definition: ( transitive ) To encounter or incur (a danger or risk).
examples: to run the risk of losing one's life

definitions.definition: ( transitive , obsolete ) To put at hazard; to venture; to risk.
( transitive , obsolete ) To tease with sarcasms and ridicule.
To sew (a seam) by passing the needle through material in a continuous line, generally taking a series of stitches on the needle at the same time.
To control or have precedence in a card game.
examples: Every three or four hands he would run the table.

definitions.definition: To be in form thus, as a combination of words.
( archaic ) To be popularly known; to be generally received.
To have growth or development.
examples: Boys and girls run up rapidly.

definitions.definition: To tend, as to an effect or consequence; to incline.
To have a legal course; to be attached; to continue in force, effect, or operation; to follow; to go in company.
examples: Certain covenants run with the land.

definitions.definition: To encounter or suffer (a particular, usually bad, fate or misfortune ).
( golf ) To strike (the ball) in such a way as to cause it to run along the ground, as when approaching a hole.
( video games , rare ) To speedrun .
( sports , especially baseball ) To eject from a game or match.
examples: Jackson got himself run in the top of the sixth for arguing a borderline strike three call.

definitions.definition: To press (a bank, etc.) with immediate demands for payment.

definitions.definition: past participle of rin
